title: Should I get an iPhone or a Samsung? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ve used lots of Samsung devices ever since 2015 up to 2019, namely the Galaxy A5, Galaxy S5, Galaxy S7 and Galaxy S9+, and I’ve changed to the iPhone XS. Here are some pros and cons of using a Galaxy and an iPhone in general from my own experience. Samsung Galaxy (Pros) : The cameras on Samsung devices ever since the Galaxy S7 onward, does a great job in low light photography.There’s a headphone jack, so you could use your wired headphones while charging the phone.Adaptive fast charging out of the box.Better external speakers, thanks to its AKG powered speakers.You’ll get a $100 AKG earphones out of the box, which sounds way better compared to Apple’s $30 earpods.There’s an option to use fingerprint unlock if you’re not a fan of facial recognition.LED-notification light, so you don’t have to turn on your screen to see whether you have any notifications (this is removed on S10 though)Expandable storage. (Not a fan of this, it makes the phone slow)Price drops very quickly. Normally you can get the phone cheaper up to 30% from just the first 4 months after launch.The software can be customized a lot. (Personally I don’t customize my phone a lot)If you opt for a Samsung Galaxy Note, you’ll have access to a stylus (s pen) which enables you to do lots productivity features.There’s an ‘always on-display’ which means you can see your more information of time, date and notification without turning on your screen.Apple iPhone (pros) : Significantly BETTER facial recognition feature to unlock the phone, thanks to its neural engine and True-depth camera system.Noticeably stronger processor. Apple’s A12 Bionic chip outperforms all android devices out there.Extremely refined software, lots of attention to detail which makes navigating the iPhone a seamless experience.A very fluid user interface. I was surprised by the fluidity that it feels years ahead compared to One UI / Stock Android 9.3D touch (pressure sensitive display) feature which makes quick options to be very handy, such as previewing videos or links. It is very integrated with the software.Ability to connect within other Apple devices such as Macbook and iPad very seamlessly.Apps and system features generally look way better compared to Android. Lots of Engineering is put into iOS.Ability to use iMessage within other Apple users. Personally, iMessage is very futuristic given all its features and integration with other Apple devices.More accessories available, and iPhone’s third party accessories look way better compared to Samsung.Supports 5–6 years of software updates.A very good and optimized battery life as for the plus models of iPhones and the X series.Significantly higher resale value and lower depreciation is better when you’re planning to sell your phone.Samsung Galaxy (Cons) : The edge display might look good, but it’s very prone to accidental touches.Only supports up to 2 years of software updates, and there are rarely any updates within the year itself.Slower and laggier user interface when compared to iOS.Phone more prone to heating up when compared to iPhones.Software is less refined, with several parts here and there of the user interface lacking of consistency.Bixby isn’t as advanced as SiriLow resale value to sell, which isn’t great if you plan to upgrade your phone every 2–3 years due to its high depreciation rate.Apple iPhone (Cons) : Less customization. (Personally I like this as it makes the UI tidier and consistent)You need to pay an extra $75 for fast chargingMore expensive to purchase due to its higher resale value and significantly lower depreciation rate.Considerably more expensive when repairing damaged parts of the phone.Cameras are bad on low-light shots.There’s no headphone jack, so you have to purchase a dongle.Despite having stereo speakers, it has a lesser sound qualityThe earpods included in the box isn’t as good as the AKG included in Samsung’s box.You need to pay extra for expanding your iCloud storage, as expandable storage is not available.Personally as a person who used Android for 4 years and moving to an iPhone, my experience have been way better in iPhone compared to Android mostly due to the iOS experience itself.

Q: Which is better to buy, the Samsung or the iPhone, and why? A: iPhone. There is no other OS with anywhere near the protection level that Apple provides. That is why you don’t see any active viruses or other hacks on Mac, iPhones or iPads, regardless of how many new strains are made. FBI Director Comey testified before United States Congress that the FBI, with the help of the other government agencies, cannot hack into iPhones, which also means that there is no way to bypass the Activation Lock/iCloud Lock, at all. He also testified that the FBI can hack all other operating systems and products, regardless of marketing claims. Companies like Cellebrite make false claims about being able to break into iPhones, the fact is that they cannot hack any iPhone that has the Secure Enclave chip, the same is true of the Manhattan District Attorney’s office who has a million dollar hacking lab, they also can only hack (All) Androids they cannot hack any iPhone that has the Secure Enclave chip in it. This is why the FBI is continuously harassing Apple to install a backdoor in to iPhones, which Apple always refuses because Apple is the only high tech company that is actually dedicated to protecting your privacy. Apple responds very quickly to new virus threats, automatically updating all Mac, iPhone and iPad users around the world immediately and invisibly. If you have Automatic Updates” turned on (which is the normal setting for all users), then you will receive updated virus protection, invisibly, the same day that Apple releases it. This is why there is no *Active* virus/malware in the Apple community, so there is nothing to worry about. Apple also avoids hardware exploits in Intel’s CPU (which have multiple security flaws) with the implementation of Apple’s own Secure Enclave, T1, T2, etc. chips that boot completely securely, regardless of all the flaws in Intel’s CPUs.
